column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Discussion
#Text=4.1. Drivers of Light Interception by Canopy
#Text=Light interception by forest canopies is driven by different features describing foliage : its vertical distribution , biomass quantity , and allocation , as well as leaf traits .
#Text=Leaf distribution across strata in tree stands is determined by canopy dominant light transmittance .
#Text=The most frequent tree species in the study area — P. sylvestris — has loose crowns , allowing higher light availability beneath its crowns than the other species .
#Text=Similarly , a small LAI to BA ratio for P. sylvestris in mature tree stands was reported by Bauer .
#Text=For that reason its stands are usually occupied by dense shrub layers , including invasive species .
#Text=For species with higher light interception , e.g. , Q. rubra and F. sylvatica , presence of shrub layers is least developed .
#Text=Different proportions of tree species in the main ( highest ) canopy layer determine overall light availability at lower forest strata .
#Text=For that reason forests with dominance of light-transmitting species in the overstory have more developed shrub layers , which also determines lower light availability at the forest floor .

#Text=However , in stands with well-developed both canopy and shrub layers , increasing LAI does not decrease DIFN , because light availability is vertically stratified — more than one layer of leaves covers open sky .
#Text=Quantity of foliage biomass depends on tree dimensions , according to metabolic scaling theory .
#Text=However , the exponent of this relationship is size-dependent , as more biomass is allocated to stems in larger trees .
#Text=Despite decreasing allocation , foliage biomass increases with stand age .
#Text=In older stands , due to self-thinning and years of light competition , more gaps provide more light into the lower strata .
#Text=Lower trees and shrubs have lower total biomass , and therefore higher biomass allocation to foliage .
#Text=For that reason we found the highest LAI to BA ratios in shrubs and the lowest in trees .
#Text=Leaf area in the canopy layer also depends on leaf architecture and functioning .
#Text=The wide range of SLA shows that for trees similar leaf mass might differ in area up to one order of magnitude .
#Text=This trait reflects plant strategy of facing limited resources and life span , as well as investment in foliage development .
#Text=Although SLA varies with climate , light availability , and growing season , interspecific variation is higher than intraspecific .
#Text=Therefore , each tree species LAI to BA ratio is also dependent on leaf morphology , compromising species-specific evolutionary legacies .
#Text=4.2. Impacts of Alien Species
#Text=We found the highest LAI to BA ratio in C. lucidus , a species coming from Central Asia .

#Text=This species is known as a naturalized , potentially invasive species in Poland , a casual neophyte in Czechia , and as naturalized in Armenia , Canada , Finland , Latvia , Norway , Russia , Sweden , the United Kingdom , and the United States .
#Text=This species is known for creating dense stands which decrease the richness and abundance of native species .
#Text=The cited authors suggested that the mechanism of negative impacts might be limiting of light availability , however , they did not provide a quantitative assessment .
#Text=In the study area C. lucidus had limited distribution — we found it only in one of the study blocks , but with high abundances .
#Text=Due to its ability to be bird-dispersed , a risk assessment is highly needed for this species , which might cause more severe impacts than the currently most frequent invasive species .
#Text=Our study showed different impacts of four main invasive tree species .
#Text=P. serotina revealed the highest LAI to BA ratio .
#Text=This species , which in Europe usually has the form of a shrub or small tree , is able to dominate lower strata of forest ecosystems .
#Text=Similar to our results , a twice higher leaf area index of P. serotina than P. sylvestris was also reported from forests in Belgium .
#Text=This influence gives P. serotina an impact , especially high in cases of changing species composition of understory vegetation .
#Text=As young regeneration of P. serotina requires light to grow , decrease of light availability would stop further invasion of P. serotina beneath already invaded canopies .
#Text=However , due to vegetative regeneration , as well as high number of seedlings able to survive in less-suitable conditions for a few years , it is able to develop a persistent sapling bank .

#Text=Although impact of P. serotina on LAI is lower than impact of native shrubs , this species is able to reach higher BA , making its quantity the most important driver of light availability modification .
#Text=Another invasive species with relatively high LAI to BA ratio is A. negundo .
#Text=This species has high SLA , which is helpful in invading pioneer vegetation of riparian forests .
#Text=This species is mid-successional , which allows it to take advantage of release opportunities from forest disturbance in riparian ecosystems .
#Text=However , it was not frequent in the ecosystem studied here , as riparian forests were not frequent .
